Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2012 04:30PM Jen78 wrote: Hi Ladies - I'm 7 months PFC now.  I thought mine was going to stay straight, but at about the 5 month mark, the curls set in.  I think I've got about 2" of hair now.  I finally broke down and got a trim a few weeks ago...just to clean up my neck and even things out a bit.  I'm still wearing my wig to work - I just don't feel like myself with the short hair.  But, the wig doesn't feel as secure as it used to and I know I need to give it up pretty soon.  I love seeing everyone's pictures knowing that a few months from now, I should have even more growth.  Gives me hope!!  After reading that I might be able to use a flat iron now, I'm definitely going to go and buy a smaller one.  I have a 2" one as I had long hair before this.  Looking forward to playing with it and seeing how my hair looks without all this weird curl in it.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2013 07:14PM Jen78 wrote: I agree with Melissa.  I didn't shave my head until day 23 or 24.  I was a few days past my 2nd treatment and it was coming out more and more.  Seeing all that scalp peeking out as well as finding the hair EVERYWHERE was really emotional.  Once I got past the initial shock of sitting down and buzzing it off, it was almost a relief.  I'd spent nearly 2 weeks watching it slowly thin.  For me, I think I needed to go through that - deep down, I was hoping I'd be special and magically keep most of my hair.  In any event, once it was gone, I quickly got used to my wig and moved on with things.  I'm 1 year PFC now and my hair is still a work in progress.  I've been using the 1/2" flat iron to straighten the top a bit so that it lays down and then leaving the back curly.  As soon as it was long enough, I pulled bangs forward and even though I never really had them before, I felt more like "me" once I had them - I think it just softened my face for me as I've never had short hair...and I've been coloring it blonde forever, but my natural color is very dark brown and I'm leaving it that way for now (and kind of liking it!).  For the past couple of weeks, I've been using the flat iron all over and I'm kind of enjoying this look.  My hair in the back is to the base of my neck or my upper back...can't wait for the sides to catch up so that it looks like it really has length!  It does feel longer to me when it's straight.  I'm wondering when the curls will start to go away and I'll get my old texture back. Hair growth is definitely an adventure.  I feel like every few days, I have a totally new head of hair to work with as it's constantly changing!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2013 11:58AM Jen78 wrote: It took me 8 months before I felt comfortable without the wig. I rarely wore it at home and I slowly stopped wearing it around close family and friends, but I had quite a bit of hair before I managed to ditch it all together. Work was the biggest hurdle for me...I felt like I was on display. But, I've gotten nothing but compliments, so I think I was my own worst critic. It's hardest for us because what we see in the mirror is so different than what we were used to seeing. I'm trying to enjoy my hair and embrace my curls. I'm 1 year pfc and it feels like it's taking forever to grow, but when I look back, it's definitely come a long way! Hang in there, ladies.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 03:55PM Jen78 wrote:

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2013 10:35AM Jen78 wrote: I admire you guys for considering keeping your hair short. I don't think I'll get to that point until my hair is all the way back to normal. I got a lot of compliments, too...but I haven't felt like myself so it doesn't really register with me. Fingers are crossed that when I get my trim today it'll allow for some sort of normal style! I'm headed to Maui next week and plan on making it very clear that I can't lose my ponytail when she cuts it, lol!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2012 04:02PM Jen78 wrote: Hi Everyone!  I love this thread - so nice to know that you've all been where I am!  I'm not sure if this question has been addresssed, but when did you know that your hair was going to curl?  I'm 3 months pfc and have a good cap of hair now - probably about an inch long in most places, but shorter up front.  So far, it looks straight but I'm wondering if maybe the curl doesn't start until it gets a bit longer.  To be honest, I've been kind of hoping it'd stay straight - I've never had curls and wouldn't know what to do with them!  I'm glad to hear the peach fuzz thing will go away!  I noticed it about a month ago and today saw that it was getting a little out of control along my jaw below my ears.  Thankfully, my wig seems to hide most of it.  I'm not sure when I'll feel comfortable going without the wig in public.  While I whip it off the moment I get home, I never leave home without it.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2012 12:56PM Jen78 wrote: Hmmm...so curls may still be in my future. I started googling hair extensions yesterday as I'm getting impatient to start feeling like my old self. I found a video of a girl who got them just a couple months PFC with just about 1/2 - 1 inch of her own hair. I kept my eyebrows and lashes through chemo. My lashes started thinning after, but were hanging in there. I woke up from my mastectomy and it was like they'd waxed me! The tape over my eyes took the bulk of my brows and lashes with it when it was pulled off. Thankfully, they've grown back fast!!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 03:11PM Jen78 wrote: Hi Liefie, I was like you - just stubble up until about 8 weeks pfc (4 rounds of TC).  I'm now 4 1/2 months PFC and I've got a full head of hair that is about 1" long all around.  It feels super slow to me, but it's finally coming in.  Yours will, too.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2012 05:20PM Jen78 wrote: slak - Great question.  I keep wondering just how much hair I need before I can get extensions.  I'm 6 months pfc today and while I have full coverage and a little over an inch all over, I'm just not used to the short look on me and would love to get some length in a hurry!

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2012 10:53PM Jen78 wrote: I am using latisse. I think it helped as my lashes are thicker than they've ever been and came back pretty quickly. I used it on my brows for awhile, too. Tonight, I am trying Nair for my face....looking forward to getting rid of all the fuzz along my jaw! So glad this board is here for suggestions like that.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 12:52PM Jen78 wrote: Like a lot of you, I've avoided support groups.  There is a Wellness Center near my house and so many people rave about it - but I could never bring myself to go.  I've had such amazing support from my husband and parents and my medical team has been great, as well.  So, I haven't felt the need yet...but when I was feeling down, I came here instead and found that it helped tremendously.  I met with a physician yesterday who specializes in Integrative Oncology.  She focuses on diet and supplements as ways to stay healthy both during and after treatment.  She had some good ideas and put them together in a way that I can implement in steps as some of them represent drastic changes (to my diet, especially).  She gave me some good supplements to try this week before my BMX and reconstruction (Lat Flaps and TE's).  Fingers crossed that they have an impact.  I'm not good about resting and not doing things for myself, so the quicker I heal, the better.  I'm about 6 weeks PFC and I'm still feeling the aches in my hips, legs and low back.  It's actually more on one side than the other and I don't notice it when I'm resting - but man, those first few steps when I stand up are misery and I look like I'm about 80 (instead of 34!).  Does that track with what some of you are experiencing?  I find that walking on the treadmill feels great - but if I overdo it, I'm useless for the rest of the day. Hope that you all had a nice weekend and are enjoying your Tuesday, so far.  I'm thinking of all of you and hoping that you're feeling better every day.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2012 02:52PM Jen78 wrote: Karmil - Thanks for the tip.  I've been back and forth about the recliner...we don't have one and I'm tempted to invest in one now.  So, it's something I'll be thinking about this weekend as I've been worried about being able to get in and out of bed comfortably.  I have a feeling I'll be spending some quality time there and I'm feeling very thankful for trashy tv and Netflix.  ;o) Wave - Our "isolation" stories mirror each other.  I'm doing better now that I'm in the office every day again (I worked from home 95% of the time during chemo) - being forced to interact has helped.  But, the first time I went to a small party I felt completely out of place...wondering if I still had anything in common with my friends!  I do - but I'm so used to the all encompassing topic of my treatment and related appointments that moving beyond that left me with little to contribute. Rachel - I've had the same free pass about my work schedule and I'm going to miss it sorely.  I LOVED working from home as much as I did.  And now being back in the office for about 3 weeks, I've only worked a few truly full days.  With my surgery pending, I've still had a lot of appointments, so I find myself working in the office for 4-5 hours and then from home in the afternoons after my mid-day appointments.  It's cushy and easy to get used to! Hope you're all having a nice day so far.  The weather here (CA) is gorgeous and I can't wait to get out of the office!  Handily enough, I see my MO today at 2, so it's another short one for me!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2012 12:05PM Jen78 wrote: Hi Everyone, Just wanted to check in. Sounds like a lot of rough weeks were had. Rachel, I hope your last round of SE's are kind to you. I had my bmx with lat flap recon on Monday and finally came home from the hospital last night. It's been a lot harder to recover than I expected. But, it went well. It took 15 hours of surgery, but she was able to save my nipples, which was considered unlikely. I haven't had a ton of pain up front, but my back incisions are uncomfortable. We got a recliner yesterday...not sure what I'd have done without it as I've barely left it since we got home, lol. I've been thinking of all of you...I hope you're able to enjoy your weekends.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 02:12PM Jen78 wrote: I'm so glad I've found this thread.  I know I'm late to be joining in, but wanted to say hi anyway.  My name is Jen and I started TCx4 on 12/8 and finished on 2/9.  So I was right there with you guys but didn't know you were here!  While I'm sorry that so many of us are still experiencing aches and pains, you have no idea how relieved I was to see that the joint and muscle pain I've had for the past few weeks isn't mine alone. I hope that you all continue to feel better and just wanted to tell you how appreciative I was to find your posts and to finally feel like I'm not alone in this.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 02:30PM Jen78 wrote: Thank you for the welcome! I had a lumpectomy to kick things off and was supposed to have radiation after chemo.  During treatment, I decided that I'd rather have a BMX (and reconstruction).  Once I talked to my MO and surgeon about my thoughts, they were both on board.  For me, it was more about peace of mind.  So, that's coming up on 3/26.  I was dx'd at Stage I, Grade 3, 0/2 lymph nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2-.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 01:12PM Jen78 wrote: Hang in there, Rachel. We're all thinking about you. As for me, no PT yet, but I think you're right and I'll push for it. I'm feeling pretty immobile at the moment. Wave- so happy to hear you've had a good week. Keep that sunny outlook going.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2012 12:41PM Jen78 wrote: Hi Ladies, I had my chemo at the same time as all of you. Finished in early February. I wish I'd found these boards sooner, but even after the fact, it's so reassuring to know we're all still experiencing a lot of the same things. Rachelvk - I have redness where my port was. I had it on my chest and upper arm while the port was in, and sometimes the skin was noticeably warmer. I took antibiotics and the warmness went away. But, 3 months after removing the port, I still have redness. I also have some swelling in that arm. One doc thinks I might have superficial blood clots (I've been checked for dvt), another thinks it's some sort of lymphedema (even though it's the opposite side)....I'm going to make an appointment with my BS and see what she thinks. I feel the scarring inside like you do, too. So many weird little things that stick around. I'll be interested to hear what your docs have to say. Hope you're all well and enjoying the summer so far!
Posts.Title: Has anyone started a Dec 2011 group? darlam mamabee

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 04:31PM Jen78 wrote:
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 05:50PM Jen78 wrote: Wave, you crack me up about feeling old.  As for it being discouraging to hear that I'm still having pain, I should clarify that it's nowhere near as bad as it was a couple of weeks ago.  The heavy feeling in my legs and the burning muscles are a memory.  I used to have the soreness when I was sitting down or laying in bed at night.  Now, it's really just when I'm up and around for a bit and it's not keeping me from doing much of anything anymore.  I can usually push through and ignore it.  For me, I think there is also some causation related to the fact that I was out of shape and not all that active prior to my diagnosis.  Since October, I've dropped 30 lbs - and I still need to drop about 50 more.  So, I'm not coming from the best place, either...but I'm getting there.  I'm so bummed that I'm going to slow down for a bit after surgery - I'm hoping that I can be doing short walks within a week or so (wishful thinking?!). Glad you've gotten started on the treadmill again.  Three weeks ago, I started and was at 1.5 mph and barely made it to 15 minutes (not sore, but so tired still from chemo).  I'm up to 3 mph and 45 minutes about 5x a week.  It gets a little easier every day and I feel so accomplished when I think about how tough it was just a few short weeks ago.  So, keep going...it's going to get better and better.  I know the radiation doesn't make things any easier, so double kudos to you!
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2012 02:35PM - edited Mar 21, 2012 02:37PM by Jen78 Wave - So glad that you're heading to the gym!  Given my lack of fitness over the past few years, it's great to actually inspire someone to exercise.  And, it works both ways.  I skipped yesterday's workout and woke up wanting to hit snooze again this morning.  But, I remembered reading about all of you working on building back up and I got myself out of bed.  I felt so much better getting ready for work this morning knowing that I'd managed to walk a mile before 6 a.m.! Karmil710 - So sorry about your laptop!  I've done the same...and destroyed 2 iPhones all in about an 18 month span - that was an expensive year for me!  I'll be anxious to hear how your TE exchange goes - you must be so excited.  My BMX is Monday, too - they tell me it'll be about an 11 hour surgery (BMX, Lat Flaps, TE's) which makes me nervous, but I'm looking forward to getting it behind me! Michelle - I had swelling in my legs and face during treatment, but nothing that altered what I was able to wear.  My MO checked my shins and ankles at every visit and the nurses asked me about it at every treatment, so I think it's something they watch.  I'm 6 weeks out and mine seems to be all but gone.  My face is back to normal and I have a small amount in my lower legs that is barely palpable.  I'm glad you're pushing for resolution - water retention can drive your blood pressure higher, which is hard on your heart. Heather B - thanks for the tip about not covering up so much at night.  I tried it and actually got a decent amount of rest last night!  The hot flashes aren't as frequent as they were, but I feel like they last longer now (it's still only a few minutes each time).  No night sweats and from the sound of things, I'm very thankful for that!  I'm knocking on wood so I don't jinx myself. CKK - Thanks!  You're right, our bodies have been through a ton in a very short period of time.  I think we all need to remind ourselves of that from time to time when we get frustrated with our limitations. Rachel - just so you know, I read your posts and feel exhausted.  You amaze me!  I've been in a kind of self-imposed isolation since diagnosis.  First because I was in shock, then because I was afraid of getting sick during treatment and now because I really just don't know how to "be" when I'm out and about anymore.  I'm getting better, but it's a weird process coming to realize that I'm just not the same person that I used to be.  Reading your stuff makes me wonder if I'd have slid back into "normal life" easier if I hadn't taken myself out of it so completely for these last few months.  I admire how active you've managed to stay.  So glad that you're nearing the finish line now.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2012 08:50PM Jen78 wrote: I've been checking this thread all day, Rachelvk. I'm so glad to hear that everything is ok. Hope you can get rid of the cough now!

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 11:51PM Jen78 wrote: Thanks for all the kind comments! Like most of you, I am trying to keep moving forward now. I'm up on my treadmill almost every morning...trying to get in shape. Hope everyone has a great night.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2012 11:27PM Jen78 wrote: Thanks, Karmil. Once I made the decision for the bmx, I was anxious to get it done. The lumpectomy was a total success, but finding out I was triple neg made me want to take the most aggressive path possible. I was 6 weeks PFC when I had the surgery and I do think that made it harder. I ended up needing blood transfusions after surgery, was checked repeatedly for clots...just a tough recovery all around. My IV failed twice and we weren't able to get it back in, so as soon as the transfusions were done, we gave it up. I had to remove my port during the bmx due to infection. But, it sure would've come in handy this past week! After all that, I still think I'd have done it the exact same way if I could go back. I had a lot of time to come to peace with it. I had a lot of "friends" telling me that I was crazy to do the bmx since I was stage 1, but I never doubted myself. I feel my meds kicking in, so my next nap is in order. Thank you all for the support. It means so much.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2012 11:36PM Jen78 wrote: Wow, can't believe how fast the first couple of weeks of rads have gone for so many of you (at least from where I'm sitting!). So glad that everyone seems to be handling them well. Rachel - hope you're over the hump and starting to feel better. So happy that this is the last time you'll go through this cycle. That article about over-diagnosis must've been everywhere. When I saw it, I got all fired up and had a whole discussion about how it didn't make any sense to me with my family (they all agree). I was only 33 at diagnosis and tend to lean toward even earlier mammo's, even though I know that's just fear talking. When I heard how much more sensitive breast MRI's are, I remember wondering why they weren't the standard of care. I'm in the camp where I'd rather have false alarms than miss something, you know? I happened to get lucky and my tumor attached to a cyst, so I felt it even though I had very dense breasts. By the time I would have had my first mammo... As for me, recovery from this surgery is harder than I expected. I'm up and around a bit and trying to do more. I've just never had anything hold me back for long and I have limited patience for it! I hope you're all doing well and starting to feel better...oh, I started latisse last night. Can't tell you how excited I was. I was looking for growth already this morning (clearly, patience is not my forte). Again, you're all in my thoughts and I'm so glad you're here.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2012 10:12AM - edited Mar 26, 2012 10:17AM by Jen78 I will post the list of supplements that were recommended, for those that asked. It's been a crazy couple of days and I left the list with my mom...who is going to pick them up for me. I asked my MO about Metformin last week and he won't prescribe it for me since it's still in trials. Part of me is thinking that I'm going to ask my regular doc for it and see how that goes. The MO did tell me that baby aspirin has shown some promise in preventing recurrence, so I'll start that after surgery. Rachel - I hope you're having a better day. Sounds like a whole bunch of junk came your way at once. I'm 6 weeks PFC and other than some aches and pains, I'm having a lot of good days. Some days are tough, but the good far outweighs the bad. You're almost there. So, while your survivor friend experienced it one way, I think you'll blow her away with how well you do. You've kept going all through treatment which is going to help you. Momof3boys - totally with you. Figuring out who we are now is tough. I've been trying to get back into my old routine as much as possible, which has helped. Sometimes I feel like if I pretend to be back to normal, eventually I will be. It's a new theory...we'll see how it goes. Hope you're all having a nice weekend.
Posts.Title: Taxotere/Cytoxan - December 2011 LeesaAnn AnnieLane

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2012 07:09PM Jen78 wrote: Baileybump - I'm sorry about your eyebrows and can totally relate. I'd held onto mine with some light thinning and was so happy about it. I looked in a mirror a couple days after surgery and the inside half of one of mine is gone!!! Tape must've gotten it during surgery. It bothered me more than I'd have guessed possible under the circumstances. Hoping it fills back in quickly. I'm with all of you on avoiding all things negative. I find that I only watch comedies lately and avoid everything else entirely. I guess we've all just had enough of the stuff that brings you down.
